@euphoriafish I know people might say to me “But you sound too utopian…that world you envision will never ever come true! So what’s the point?” to which I will say
@euphoriafish and even no such concepts as those of disordered/disabled people but these people are just people - like any others.

@euphoriafish In the world where every citizen is naturally aware of these ideas, I envision that there would be no discrimination, no hatred, no denial of essential rights for those who are considered disordered/disabled,

@euphoriafish and not standing in the way of others with bad intentions of stopping them from pursuing excellence of any degrees in what they are passionate about - and overall, building systems that structurally support these ideas, financially, politically and through various possible means.

@euphoriafish If my understanding goes true with what “diversity” and now-overused word “neurodivergent” essentially are (or should have been) about, those are acknowledging all these richness that different people bring to the world, help others find their seeds of special interests,

@euphoriafish And yes, you don’t always have to name those things as talents because we’re all interested in different things at different levels, and “talents” as I spelled it refer to all those things that people do good at, no matter how much good.

@euphoriafish The point is, autistic or not, and disordered/disabled or not, it’s the diversity of people and the richness of their talents that enable our civilization to function in interdependent structures. Proven to be quite effective, btw.
@euphoriafish We’d need plumbers, garbage collectors, firefighters and even sewage cleaners - names of probably the least appreciated professions.

@euphoriafish Our civilization would easily cease to exist would there only be stock traders, programmers, politicians, lawyers and doctors - just listing a few names of those in typically-high-paying jobs.
@euphoriafish but first, I think we probably need to acknowledge that our economy/society and their existences depend heavily on the diversity of peoples’ talents.
@euphoriafish I know this sounds like I’m overstating people with traits/characteristics that stand out (for better or worse) from the rest of the population,
@euphoriafish Luckily, no.

If being at your natural best is what makes you authentic, any forced attempts to fake any parts of that should be clearly taught to be inauthentic just so you won’t end up hurting yourself - aware or otherwise.
If there’s any practical use of the stuff I learned from masking, that’s about all. There’s not a whole lot that’s valuable.

Learning to emulate the viewpoint of NTs, I learned how I differed from them in a few ways if not in all ways. And by pushing myself more towards the autistic direction well beyond how autistic I actually am, I now know how to be the funniest person in certain situations.
Although this may discomfort some of those reading the following tweets, there are a few  things that could be benefited from the person masking. Or at least I see them.
Just in time for the event, my father had a job abroad and moving out of the toxic environment was finally a real thing in my life. I was super lucky that I found my life’s worth after moving abroad.
Thankfully, with all of the outer layers taken off of my actual personality (which in its process brought me back to the state I was in at 5yo), I was able to rebuild myself upon that.
Eventually my brain was no longer capable of containing them both inside as they started to contradict from each other in ways so numerous. I had to scrap them both.

The real horror was that I was fully committed to building an imaginary personality that would never ever be real  (but didn’t see it that way) and I kept stripping useful bits out of my actual self so that the imaginary me would grow into the real thing.
This was when my shortcomings were being made obvious and exposed to my classmates by 4th grade teacher, in manners very appropriately described as abusive.

I have personally chosen not to refer to “them” as traumas but I recall that faking myself (especially beyond my capabilities) created an imaginary personality that didn’t even have eyes, nose and mouth on its face.

Even when the person chooses not to refer to the outcome of the masking as trauma, it’s quite obvious that the person could easily lose track of the actual personality over time. And filling the gap between the masked and the actual turns into an enforced effort. Very unhealthy. https://t.co/I54vidoE1x

@euphoriafish Then ADHD comes back in either saying “Hey, how about you work on that thing you did a while ago? Looks fun again, you know?” OR “I have fresh candidates of additions to your new hobbies!” and the process goes on, switching between ADHD and ASD.

@euphoriafish Then the ASD somehow kicks in, enabling me to hyperfocus on the interesting stuff just found - and it lasts as long as until I temporarily get fed up (by this point my brain is usually exhausted 🥱).

@euphoriafish As for numerous things of my interests that would most appropriately be called obsessions by many people (even though I have long referred to them as my hobbies), it’s usually the curious mind of ADHD that first finds interesting additions.
@euphoriafish What have, however, helped me excel in things that I intuitively have are - very ironically - ASD part of me and ADHD part of me being effective at different times.

@euphoriafish I must also confess that how my brain behaves is mostly uncontrollable to me in ways very similar to how a trike equipped with an F1 engine may seem virtually uncontrollable. I know my brain could go flying fast when it decides to do so, but it also frequently crashes into trees.
@euphoriafish While I must admit that I occasionally feel my brain outperforms those of many others and that some people may see that part of me as my superpower,
It’s very much like engraving it in my brain, and the technique is somehow only available for use like four times a year. And I don’t get to pick when the technique becomes available.
So, the way by which a forgetful ADHDer that I am manage to remember something over a long period of time is by literally taking a visual snapshot of the scene in which a particular event happened.

I secretly believe that the neurodivergents are in fact the majority, not minority - and that we humans just don’t know that yet.
These are my reasons.

Frankly, it seriously pisses me off.
I am very uncomfortable with these words because they show that people don’t give a s**t about difficulties associated with being smarter by IQ - something I daily go through.

Would this make me happy? Maybe for no longer than 0.1s - but then followed by the words full of anger rushing up my throats for eruptions:
“What do you know about that? Do you think being smarter makes my life easier than yours? Do you even know I pay extra costs for that?”
Next, I hate this typical treat of words: “But that means you are smart!”

I am not proud of the fact that I lack the ability to imagine the life-experiences of others EVEN THOUGH I AM CONSIDERED HIGH-FUNCTIONING BY WHICH WORDS I FEEL BEING FORCED TO FEEL THAT I SHOULD BE ABLE TO IMAGINE THEM. Yet I just can’t.

And while I must admit that I am one beneficiary of being on the high-functioning side, I feel shameful about my inability to imagine how the life would be for people who were born and raised in ways completely different from what I went through.
How would a person be made to feel when being told that she/he is low-functioning? I dare not to imagine because it sounds painful beyond my imagination.
First, the expression “high-functioning” when thought extensively in contrast brings the idea of “low-functioning” to existence.
Yet, I do find the title being a very valid statement. And I am giving my reasons.
Following how my ADHD goes in terms of getting stomach-full upon reading the titles of topics discussed, I won’t be watching the video I have just retweeted.

Where those seemingly neurotypical had masks off and standing closed to each other for their usual socialization, I, feeling quite angry about their behaviors, specifically stayed away from them by being on a different floor where more people alike were far less densely situated.

And one of the natures of my ASD, of that I tend to strictly stick to rules where absolutely necessary, seems to have saved me from being infected by the COVID-19 even though I have gone to clubs a few times between Mid-Feb 2020 and Mid-Jan 2022.
I do admit that the ADHD part of me has requested a few times that I go out for extra fun outside of home, yet suppressing the urge to go out has so far been very easy for some reasons.

Because I have several things that I could be obsessed about (and I hop between them like ADHD would make a person behave so), all I have had to do is find fun things from the list of obsessions that could be done at home. Very simple.
For me having both ASD and ADHD, the experience has been a very mixed kind although enjoyable overall.

One of the highlights of the whole COVID-19 and lockdown experiences is there are people who can tolerate being forced to stay at home at extreme levels, and the revelation made it more obvious than we’ve ever known that the society before was built for those who can’t tolerate.

And I believe that such is the closest mankind could possibly get to “understanding people of the other side” because we (neurodivergent or not) all know that we can’t possibly picture or imagine what it’s like to be on the other side unless the experiences can be felt.

I personally believe that achieving a neurodivergent-friendly society requires the spread awareness of the concept of “agree to disagree” by which both neurotypicals and neurodivergents will learn “not to get in the way of others by too much”.

The worst enemy of people with autism, IMHO, are people who by their traits are reasonably autistic and are not aware themselves - and especially those who try to force others to endure what they have had to endure. Very toxic.

I personally don’t see NTs as this group of people that are heartless or harming. You may not often come across, but the group of people that I actually would refer to as NTs are quite harmless although they may not see what we see.

What gets me puzzled oftentimes, however, is when people share very personal things about themselves. I very much appreciate the kind of trust they show me by doing that, but then, because I am not very used to people showing so much trust, I often do not know how to react.
There’s nothing that’s really discomforting to me as long as none of the people around me appear to be intentionally threatening or hurting me.

As far as I can say for myself, my words are ones my brain picked so that the images (some people call them thoughts) sitting and behaving in organic manners in my head could be most accurately described.
Essentially, that’s how brains of so many auties function. And those ideas that get created in our minds are not easily shared with many because they often are visual and not verbal.

I have no evidence that those designers/engineers were autistic, but I can say with some degree of confidence that they were visual thinking types of people whose ideas most likely came from connecting ideas in their minds.
I also want you to imagine the kind of people who would have spent countless hours on designing (well into details) the mechanisms of most machineries that drive the world today.
I just want you to imagine the kind of people who would have spent countless hours on designing (well into details) the styles of clothing we wear today.
I don’t mean to behave as a person with stilted attitude, and I certainly don’t enjoy behaving like I represent the entire community of auties, but I hope that I have some points.

And while I must admit that I only skimmed through the objectives yesterday, I must also tell you that I was inexplicably fascinated to find in-depth objectives of 17 SDGs put forth by ILO. Take a look.
https://t.co/ctCkVtrvhJ

Yet I am tweeting about SDGs not because I have been brainwashed to brainwash you, but because I genuinely think it’s worth trying to inspire you to take a look at what the objectives say, especially if you happen to be living a life with full of difficulties.
Many of the objectives seen in SDGs may sound cheesy to you today because we are still in early stages of the transformation.

Now including objectives to make sure that we will be living in a world where norms are significantly different from what we have today and with less opportunities wasted, SDGs are in progress of perfecting its objectives.

And if my words don’t inspire you to believe that the would could be a better place - possibly well beyond your imaginations, consider that MDGs (now superseded by SDGs) proposed by the United Nations saw many of its objectives met over the last decades.

Over the next decade (during years leading to 2030 to be specific), I expect to see that the world will transform into a place different from what we could imagine based on what’s being possible today.
Maybe you are wrong far less often than you would naturally want to think you are, and you just need a set of strategies distinguishably different from those effective for others around you.

Living a life powdered by a brain that they appear to describe as disordered could be a challenge, and it sure often seems that way. But that doesn’t mean you can’t have a fulfillment in your life, or a life full of joy.

And when not many people seem to like you, it’s probably not always because you have certain conditions or diagnosis, but maybe more often because you have uninspiring qualities in your attitudes towards fulfilling your life, and maybe those are what people do not like about you.

No name of neurodevelopment disorder you have been labeled with should ever make you feel like you are an “incomplete” or “failed” version of what they seem to praise as NTs - because you just are not.

After all, you are smarter and stronger than yesterday. Know that you are always making progress because you are alive (that is, you could have died by now if you hadn’t).

But remember that you of today is being a possibility very much thanks to you of yesterday.

And this is one of the simplest ways by which you could start rebuilding your self esteem - if you don’t know how to already.
May the peace be with your mind.
#ActuallyAutistic #ActuallyADHD

One asset of mine that I was allowed to assess its value during this time was the unrivaled resilience against being forced to stay at home - in fact we, many of ASDers, tend to prefer to stay at home and ultimately being daily left alone for some time. #ActuallyAutistic

Being absolutely honest, I,as a person who is #ActuallyAutistic, enjoyed being in the world that for a while looked like a broken place regarding how things were before the pandemic. In place where people like me normally felt like they were broken, it was quite an experience.

@HowtoADHD What we do need to be good at, perhaps, is to keep the masking habit at a healthy level and never ever push it beyond that point. And healthy masking habit in my definition includes the assumption of there being concepts to allow us to be ourselves where and when needed.

@HowtoADHD What I know at this point is that masking is something we may naturally practice as one of valid strategies to socially fit in better, but that enforced masking, especially when the enforcing gets too much, can severely damage the mental health of the person masking.

@HowtoADHD It was terrifying mostly because I couldn’t see the exit, or what was happening to me next.
With all these details explained in words out of my mind, it’s very likely that I would be diagnosed with Dissociative Disorders had it taken place 25yrs later.

@HowtoADHD That day in September of 1996, I was in the bathroom trying to vomit all of the disintegrations out of me, and it was really terrifying. In addition to the series of pains I felt (that I mentioned earlier), it felt as if the world was getting turned upside down in ten minutes.

@HowtoADHD There were widening gaps between them that my brain instinctively felt that it had to fill somehow. I started lying without realizing that I was lying. And then I hit the wall with those gaps still apparent. I basically crashed mentally.

@HowtoADHD Two personalities inside me: one actual inside, one virtual on the surface.
Even though the virtual part was very probably meant to be temporary thing, the actual never caught up with the virtual.
@HowtoADHD “a little harder”: at least that’s how my teacher thought. Yet he also used the expression as if it were one actually valid excuse to rightfully bully me, putting me to shame and stuff.

@HowtoADHD Expectations for how I would socially fit in better had I tried only “a little harder” and the picture I saw of it being impossible quickly disintegrated my identity. I was in two pieces: the person I wish I were, and the person I was.

@HowtoADHD I recall that day in grade 4 that I was having all sorts of pain I could possibly have both in my stomach and head, feeling my soul completely out of my body. This was when I was going through what I consider to be the hardest time of my life.

And I was literally turned into a flattened object on the floor. My brain crashed.
I had heard warnings going off in my head and was now paying the fine for ignoring them.

I thought my motivation was a lot more controllable even with narcolepsy, so I tested myself to see how much my body can handle - specifically where I feel that all I need to do to have a breakthrough is to take that one extra step in spite of the motivation that’s spent by then.

What I am trying to say is that things that previously seemed controllable to that person may suddenly become the uncontrollable, and when that happens, what may have sounded like silly excuses out of that person’s mouth are no longer silly but serious that deserve to be heard.
Now, don’t get me wrong: I’m not up for the competition for who is living the life with more difficulties on the way. That’s to be avoided the most IMHO.

If I were to name things that I today would, more than anything else, refer to as invaluable assets of mine, those would be all of the curiosities of mine fulfilled during those years that I lived without a sleepy head.
I very much hated assignments, but things I assigned myself to figure out endlessly kept me digging deeper, and then-night-owls that I was took full advantage of that.

So many of fellow ADHDers I am guessing are night owls. And I consider you to be on the luckier side of the tribe, because I recall how I dealt with things of my interests before any traces of my narcoleptic traits showed up. #actuallyadhd #actuallynarcoleptic

And it’s things like these that, one by one (and they pile up to a height), make auties feel that they are not being understood.

Then what do auties do? - They shut up in denial of communication where auties felt the same way. And people start thinking auties are non-verbal…?

Why couldn’t they have taken an extra 15 seconds to realize that not all auties “cannot communicate” but that auties are more likely to hit roadblocks in communicating with others (i.e. some auties would actually talk too much)?

And then we look at examples of quite definitive expressions about us which are - if not always - often wrong, very wrong.
And this confuses the hell out of me.
I’m highlighting the matter because people on the spectrum are often described as inflexible with their thoughts in that they don’t seem to see the in-between options between yes and no.
Before I start sounding too critical of the tweet that I made reference to, let me clarify that I said I hate that expression, not that I think it’s wrong.

Sure, some might be non-verbal - but given the state of diagnostic criterion today (by which no distinction would be made between former auties and former aspies), the expression used here is hardly realistic and instead sounds too harsh on many of those on the spectrum.

Straight out, I hate this expression “cannot communicate”.
It displays the general assumption that virtually all autistic kids are incapable of verbal communication - which in my view is precisely where pretty much all of misunderstandings begin. https://t.co/ThAnRNY6rH

Well, now I don’t know what to do with this person. I sense, though, that it’ll be either I will end up blocking her, or I get blocked by her first.

Am I being insane? I don’t think so. It’s about people maintaining (or breaking) trusts with me.
I believe I reserve the right to block a user should I feel that I need to do so...but then there was a person who DMd me about the issue, saying that I need to hold my words inside...
I, in discomfort I couldn’t possibly express with words, quote-retweeted saying that I was in discomfort with the tweet, and that I was blocking the person.

My assumption probably was profoundly wrong...basically a person who followed me (by sending me a request) tweeted stuff that would sharply trigger flashbacks, carelessly touching almost all of my traumas.

I’ve long assumed those sending me requests (who also have conditions in common with mine) at least carried a decent thoughts, of that people suffering from the conditions REALLY REALLY SUFFER A LOT and that THEY WOULD NATURALLY AVOID WRITING TWEETS THAT WOULD TRIGGER TRAUMAS...
But now I see clear reason for which I have to do so.

To this day, I’d never thought of adding the following phrase to my bio - “if you don’t know me in person and/or have never had any conversations with me through any of the other accounts I own, I will not accept your request. Please DM  me first.”
Yet some users don’t understand my intention of keeping the account as private and send me requests so they could follow.

The reason for which I keep my other account (with tweets in Japanese only) private, is because “there’s just so much going on within the community of people with disorders, often with harsh words” and “I wanted a quiet room without those flying in”.
I just couldn’t stand it and simply blocked the user.

I’m confused and also very frustrated with people who appear on the timeline of my other “disordered” account, who say they have conditions similar to mine - yet also say “But hey, I’m still in my early 20s, I’ve got a decent job and other things I could feel happy about.”

What I learned as a teenager - The harder you try to regulate your own behaviors (so that others around you won’t feel as uncomfortable), the more frequently you are told that they are not happy with what you do.
They subconsciously know that you are easily confused and abused

The point is, there are moments we want to be left alone just like there are moments we feel lonely and insecure, or even horny. Reading our emotional timings may be difficult, but it really helps to have more people around me and within my sight, to understand the complexity.

I wrote this part because it’s also true, at times, that having someone tell me “You’re not alone. Tell me what you are worried about.” is as annoying as I’d be driven nuts by those words.
https://t.co/PhyLRUdR8U

Yet I would greatly appreciate if you cared more for those screaming out the agony of feeling alone, than, say, you ever have before. Chances are, we’ll be living in a better world once the #COVID19 is over. Yes, I believe we will be.

Let me add though, that people like me who tend to travel back and forth between two worlds - of my own and of ours - are difficult for others to cope with. We have swinging moods with irregularities.

Assuming this, I strongly felt that those who are feeling alone, insecure and anxious (before getting to feel horny) should be more softly accepted on saying that they need to feel like they are not alone.

These things I either knew or recently found out about, all put together, lead me to a rough conclusion that the four words of “I’m so horny...” as frequently seen on those Discord servers, is no different from “I need to feel someone near, because I feel insecure being alone...”
It’s also true to me that when I’m hyper -focusing on stuff that fuel my soul, those horniness are very negligible.
I’ve long been aware and hence understood that the sense of being horny is often very closely linked to the person’s desperate need for feeling connected with someone, being near them.

It doesn’t mean I’m no longer holding the naughty intentions I first had (although I would like to say I am - but they are by far less). The way I feel about those conversations is, however, very different compared with before.
Yes, I did have rather naughty intentions when I joined those servers (in fact two incl. one I already left), but now I feel quite calm about whatever the conversation there may be going on.

I see Discord servers that are intended for adult conversations are receiving more newcomers than ever, and well, it’s rather epic to see someone go “I’m so horny...” and other keep going “me too...”, till someone says “we all are, for having joined this server.”
So, it seems that so many of those staying at homes with nothing fun to do in this turbulent time are hornier than they’ve ever been before.
Sorry if you are discomforted by the following, but there’s a conclusion I intend to get to. Hope you would read on before unfollowing me or blocking me.

There has been a report published in Japanese by a doctor who works at the hospital where they had the first case of #COVID19 leading to death in the country, and the reading I found was rather interesting to look into,

And as an outsider to the medical industries, I’d like to point out that professionals having access to the right set of tools at the right time and place surely helps, even if the general public doesn’t directly benefit from that.

but thankfully the spread isn’t happening as rapidly as otherwise. 
I, as an ordinary citizen based around Tokyo, can’t thank medical professionals enough for all the expertise and efforts they put into their work at their war-zone like work environment.

Shortage of test-kits isn’t just in countries where the spread of #COVID19 is happening at highest paces, and on top, people in Japan have bad practices of “going as usual” when they think they have a cold (potentially being the biggest contributor to the spread of #COVID19),
they also have access to dependable tools to help them (relatively accurately) make decisions on testing the patient for #COVID19 or not.

This isn’t a show-off, and is certainly not something I say with the tone of “other countries should do the same”, but is something I would like to mention in this event of #COVID19 outbreak/pandemic that medical professionals in Japan do suffer from shortages of test-kits while
and that Japan is one of a few countries where you were only minutes away from those “modalities” should doctors request the scanning done on you. Not days or weeks.

What I know from those days is that nearly all (or at least 80% or more, as I got the impressions of such) of hospitals/medical institutions in Japan - including ones you’d go to when you have mild cold - have CT scans at least,
When common-place PCs of the time barely carried 1GB of RAM, those software required to be run on workstations with two Quad-Core processors with 2GB RAM in all 8 slots.

The processed images would typically provide the reconstructed images of the scanned section in 3D, allowing the medical staff to rotate them in any directions, get any cross-sectional images and even extract specific parts like vains and bones.

I’ve previously worked for a company that developed software to be run on top-spec workstation (monster-fast PC) that would take hundreds images from so-called modalities (CT scan, MRI, and so on...) at once and process.

As somebody who happens to be both #ActuallyAutistic and #ActuallyADHD who has been kicked out of higher education scheme for these conditions along with #Narcolepsy,
(And ADHD kicks in...can't finish this today...)
Somewhere along the course, I decided that "numerous" friends wasn't for me, so slowly shifted to deepening the ties with a few friends with whom bi-directional understanding would occur.
This lead me to a long-lasting bullying in which I lost hope for establishing friendships that otherwise would have been numerous...

Moving on with my life, I had difficult times in the elementary school...I'm not going to go into details, but forgetting assignments and inevitable unbalanced diet (plus  the food-education system at school that did not allow it) got me in the position of troublesome student.
I admired girls for daily wearing skirts that to me did not look like their thighs were tied up.

4yo was also when I saw a rising question inside me, on the correctness of my gender. And I think I know what triggered it - sensory issues deeply associated with that I had to wear rather tight pants every day - I simply did not like it.
But let me say honestly, that I didn't care who's boy or girl back then. It's just that I needed someone who'd play with my after Kindergarten or on days Kindergarten would not be open.

But the story doesn't end there.
Those who saw the situation would also testify that my first flirting was when I was 4yo, after the entering ceremony of Kindergarten. The girl today is shockingly beautiful that I must also say I had great tastes already at 4yo.

Starting from the conclusion, I think I'm a born-feeling-lonely person and the need for feeling someone (that I trust) near me is always one of the top priorities. My parents recall that I wasn't able to sleep alone in a baby-bed.

I know their partners have reasons to know and/or to be told about periods, but what about me following the accounts of some women who, without hesitation, tweet about their periods or it nearing?

Imagine tens of minutes of being able to stay awake the whole length of MWT tests.
For control, as always, they'd used placebo in such tests but the differences were so obvious that the use of placebo had been virtually ineffective. It is that powerful.

Won't give you detailed numbers for security, but in early tests of TAK-925, patients were given the amount of orexin calculated to be "theoretically necessary". The results in a nutshell were marvelous as they reacted sharply to the substance administered to them.

I'm trying to figure this out because I see insecurities inside her, of the kinds that are unfamiliar to me, and because I want to know how accurate my observations are. More precisely, what would happen when she is no longer young and popular, but feels alone one day like I did?

So, the question arose: What are the differences in factors that made
a.)her the optimistic, charismatic (and sometimes arrogant) and the loved person that she is
b.)me the pessimistic, lonely (and usually modest) and previously-bullied person that I am

After having rather personal conversations with her, I realized and she also agreed that the ways in which her brain functions are very similar to those of mine (to such extent she seems like a clone of me) although the apparent behaviors of mine and hers differ a lot.

For my part, "feeling lonely" - hence my inborn insecurity already apparent months after my birth - has only given me a few close friends and a broken heart now held together with the glue of mindfulness. For all the pain I experienced, it also cares for those who are mistreated.

She also expresses that she has never found her life any difficult but has always been very fun (although she also says she would not mind losing her life right now, which I find is a bit hard to understand).

I recently came to know that she got to diagnosis #ADHD (and #ASD too, possibly) after being told by her classmates in ways that are somewhat casual if not rude, that she must have Asperger's. She however recalls classmates accepted her and bullying was irrelevant to her.

Her tendencies of being overly inclined to know certain people (btw, that's when the skewed sense of personal space becomes apparent) and/or topics of her interests (carried out in impulsive manners) are very puzzling especially for male followers, people nevertheless like her.

"charismatic" I believe is the word to best describe the distinctiveness of the autistic person that she is as far as regarding her words on twitter. The way she behaves is like your imaginary sister who is younger than you and who is also super-curious.

The finding is, a girl in her 20s with #ADHD (presumably on the spectrum of #ASD as well) is somewhat popular in some place online. I am also a fan of her and can tell she has #autism because of the skewed sense of personal spaces and those moments when "words go over her head".

This may have already been discussed by professionals or else I am on my own with just a single unclear case of #autism to base my views on (and note that I am not a medical professional of any kind).

The last two weeks have been tough ones for me but taking some time to remember and then to try to face your childhood memories (good or bad) has allowed me understand the person I start off as and the person I was meant to grow into. Thank god I feel more relaxed now. #autism

These ideas were hardly accepted where I came from, and I'm sorry, but I could not take it any more - hence here I am.

For those with #autism, Twitter in the same way as sex I mentioned in the previous tweet is mind-healing and must also be addictive.
And guess what - nobody should ever be ashamed of what they love doing during the day and at night because those together make the person's life.

Because life is often truly hard for those with #autism, an #autistic person being able to keep going strong means s/he requires lots of self-esteem and soul-healing. A truly satisfying sex is not the only way to achieve it, but am just saying it is a working solution.

A real feeling of being loved by someone you truly care about - be it any of those get from any types of interactions with that person incl. sex - is really mind-healing. This is not an advocate for teenagers, but I say I was lucky to have found it at the age of 17. #autism

I personally see no border between a true love and a good satisfying sex - neither do others who have ever been any serious relationship.

- This sounds so erotic that it should be censored?
Well, not so much in English, AFAIK.

Love and sex, as I've long fundamentally believed, are the two inseparable elements that also have the power to heal those damaged hearts of #autism. All I wanted to do was convey that message, but mentioning the word "sex" was already a taboo. How else could I have done it?

The trouble I had in the community I was chatting with was language-dependent and was that indirect implication of sexual matters was nearly impossible should I have meant to say anything in clear tones.
I now just hope that I can make a steady progress on making improvements on my characteristics. I'm serious on this one.
